title: 10 things is way too many, just list 5 "things that might be wrong"
body: convert variable names to something better, at least "nThings" instead of tenThings

title: Implement optional "auto mode" that reduces time from stack trace to edit to as short as it takes for GPT to respond
Begin infrastructure for feedback and testing
body:
We should do this extremely incrementally, and this should be broken out into smaller tasks once begun. The first we're likely to need are:
- Basic recording of what user does, just data dump somewhere, so when we start getting alpha users we can see how they're acting/what requests they're making
- Testing framework to compare efficacy of different models/prompts/other tactics
- Feedback loop: find ways to capture hints as to whether our output was seen as useful, but most importantly have some common framework for doing this kind of thing and training with it

title: Integrate GPTIndex for better embeddings store
body:
Keep it local for now. Should have a separate embeddings store for each repository/workspace, or even better maybe there's a way of providing tags or something. Look into Pinecone as well, but don't want to do this yet. Build out a nice foundation here, we'll be using it a lot.

Start here! https://gpt-index.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/starter_example.html

title: Fault localization #3: Use similarity search in conjunction with stack trace to make selections about what code to include
Generate unit test button in debug panel
body:
Should generate a failing test (if it can't, say so), then immediately that stack trace should be placed into the stack trace textarea.

Steps:
- Button to generate unit test
- Textarea to show the unit test OR open an editor beside with the test
- Figure out how to run the unit test. I'm thinking maybe have a dedicated hidden folder (in our directory), then there is another button to "include test in my testing suite" that pastes it into <file_being_tested's_directory>/tests/<test_file_name>

title: Fault-localization #4: Use some legit tactics to select important code. Spectrum-based, etc...
Fault-localization #2: Given stack trace, eliminate levels that are obviously not useful
body:
There's already some code in the fault-localization file that ignores files from certain folders, like node_modules, /bin, etc...

I think that the first level could often be eliminated (for example, if it's inside an if __name__ == "__main__" that does nothing but call "app()" or something. If nothing comes up, this can be ignored

title: Fault-localization #1: Given a file/lineno, select some of the context around it to include. This probably means the entirety of the function prior to the line
Think through how to design tool if you are debugging software not running locally
body: From what Anish says, he rarely spins up docker containers for local dev env to find bugs, unless it is a really complex bug

title: Add telemetry before we share any software with testers, so we can see how (much) they use it
Share debug collaborator with Anish and get feedback
Share unit test generation capabilities with Anish and get feedback
Follow up with Marcin about state of unit test generation PR review
Better understand how people use "fixture datasets" with pytest
body: From call with Anish, he mentioned that they have a fixture dataset he could use for paramterized objects, but he usually does not use large objects for unit tests

title: Look into more potential places to get context and create issues
body:
From the call with Anish:
- DataDog
- Sentry
- Incident.io
- Zendesk

title: use tool context + LLM to fill in some initial debugging info
body: Now that we have can grab context via `config.yaml` from GitHub Issues, Slack threads, and txt files, pass this context to GPT-3 to fill in some initial debugging info (e.g. goal, intended behavior, current behavior, files, code sections, etc)

title: Explore how we might better focus developer on relevant files
body:
Ideas
- what files have been changed now
- what files have been changed recently
- when were files changed
- previous versions of code sections
- files where there are imports
- https://github.com/basin-dev/unit-test-experiments/issues/32

title: Pull in context from other tools at the start of a task
body:
Probably start with what we use...
- Text files
- GitHub Issues / PRs
- Slack

Future tools that might worth potentially integrating
- Notion
- Jira
- Coda

UX
- Developer connects app to Slack, GitHub, etc one time
- When starting a new task, developer drops links to the relevant GitHub, Slack, etc.
- Initial context pulled from these tools and presented to developer, who can edit it

title: Try out a couple of basic linting prompts
body: It's really easy to display words to the right of lines of code, which is great for nudging about what might be a small error. We should try a few prompts like "Is there anything wrong with this code, and at which line?" or "Are all errors handled?" or "Can this code be made more readable?"

title: Figure out a decent way to suggest fixes other than completely replacing
body:
Basically you can highlight lines red and green, but there's no way to add a button over the top of a VSCode editor. You might be able to decide based off of cursor position, change the cursor type depending on hover, etc... but should fall back to just a basic yes/no quickentry after a bit

Also, I'm assuming Copilot uses decorations to show tab completions, or else it has access to some custom API. But you could do something like that which is keyboard controlled.

- pointer cursor -> hover provider -> get info about where user is hovering -> tell them to click to accept -> keyboard shortcuts, like arrow up/down do select between ranges
	●	If you cmd+enter on a quick action, there is a refactor preview. This could be good for stuff
	●	cmd+enter to accept, cmd+shift+enter to reject, cmd+j/k for up/down, escape to clear suggestions (reject all), jump to next suggestion after one is cleared, maybe can control cursor so only up/down is needed. Or get j/k going. Backspace to reject
	●	Figure out how copilot adds the button above the line
	●	https://code.visualstudio.com/api/extension-guides/scm-provider#source-control-view

title: Try to be slightly more clever with how we do fault localization
Look into this context hacking approach
body: [CoCoMIC: Code Completion By Jointly Modeling In-file and Cross-file Context](https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.10007)

title: Start from bottom of stack-trace and work your way up until you find "blacklisted" file paths, like the bin.
Check out Hypothesis and property-based testing
body:
I think it's a promising direction to generate the property-based tests functions, and then let something like hypothesis come up with the actual examples. This is similar to what I was thinking of doing with fuzzing, but more well formalized

https://github.com/HypothesisWorks/hypothesis/tree/master/hypothesis-python#hypothesis

title: Remove duplicate fixtures?
body: Try some basic string matchers first. You'll of course want to check that all the tests still pass after any change.

title: Pull out individual assert statements
Check out static analyzers: Can we make smarter suggestions than the VCCode lightbulb?
body:
See here for some static analyzers that exist for python: https://luminousmen.com/post/python-static-analysis-tools
I think we could use these to detect errors and then make actual code suggestions about how to fix them.
